author: Trevor Hoey
title: Horizon narrows for Computershare
text:
Computershare's lack of top-line growth is a concern given the group has made several acquisitions. by Trevor Hoey Computershare's fiscal 2015 result received an extremely negative response from investors and failed to draw many positive comments from brokers both in terms of the group's performance over the past 12 months or its outlook for 2016.
The company's shares plunged from $11.70 on the day prior to the result being released to close at $10.61 and went on to trade below $10 later in the week, a level it hadn't hit for nearly two years. Of further concern was the volume of shares traded, the highest since 2011.
The provider of share registration and wide ranging corporate administration services generated a net profit of $US153.6 million ($208.3 million), down 38.9 per cent compared with the previous corresponding period.
The lack of top-line growth is a concern given the group has made several acquisitions. Deutsche Bank summed it up well saying, "Computershare's fiscal 2015 result and 2016 earnings per share growth guidance serve as a simple reminder that organic profit growth remains a challenge, leaving its overall growth outlook hostage to higher interest rates."
The broker is of the view that higher margin income should underpin a strong earnings growth story post fiscal 2016. But this long-term picture is seen to be factored into the share price and Deutsche Bank lowered its price target by 11.6 per cent from $13.80 to $12.20.
The broker also cut its profit expectations for fiscal 2016 by nearly 10 per cent to $US307.6 million. This forecast is broadly in line with Bell Potter's expectations and both brokers have a hold recommendation on the stock.
Bell Potter is more conservative with its price target, having reduced it by 16 per cent from $13.70 to $11.50. The broker said it considers the current fiscal 2016 price-earnings multiple of circa 14 to be appropriate for a business lacking growth.
Trevor Hoey
